columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to define shelf registration.

## 15.11a 

A method in which an issuing company files investments issuance that will be issued on the stock exchange with the Securities and Exchange Commission is known as shelf registration.

Shelf registration is a method that publicly listed firms apply to take advantage of positive economic situations in terms of trading instruments. When an issuer recognizes good economic circumstances, the issue can be publicly issued even without having to pay again a registration fee.

## 15.11b 
Firms may employ a dribble method of additional stock issue with shelf registration. Dribbling is the process of a firm registering an issue and hiring an underwriter to act as its sales agent. However, there are also refute against shelf registration, including the following:

1. The cost of additional issues is increasing; and

2. A market overhand will result from shelf registration.

### The cost of additional issues is increasing

In response to the increasing costs of additional issuances, the payment of investors is reduced. This is due to the underwriters' inability to provide sufficient relevant data to prospective investors. As a result, selling issues by section may be more costly for the issuer.

### A market overhand will result from a shelf registration

Shelf registration will cause a market overhand, resulting in lower market pricing. This suggests that the company might increase its investment supply; however, it will negatively influence the stock price.
